The way that fitness is scaled indeed has a significant effect at the spe=
ciation level of NEAT.  Because the number of offspring that a species will=
 produce collectively is proportional to its average fitness (which follows=
 from fitness sharing in NEAT), scaling fitness in different ways will caus=
e offspring to be allocated to species in different proportions.  

I don't=
 think there is a harm in exponential fitness if you want to emphasize the =
curve in certain ways.  The same motivations that apply in regulars EAs can=
 apply to NEAT.

However, the place where fitness scales can hamper NEAT is=
 if they are proportionally too narrow.  For example,  if every species has=
 an average fitness between 1001 and 1005, then they will look practically =
the same to fitness sharing and will all get roughly the same number of off=
spring.  In that case, speciation won't really distinguish much between bet=
ter and worse species.  However, if the average fitnesses were instead betw=
een 1 and 5, then the allocations would vary a lot, with many more offsprin=
g going to the 5 species than the 1 (because 5 is 5 times 1).  This example=
 shows that the range of fitnesses is not the only important consideration.=
  It is also important how big the range is compared to the absolute magnit=
ude.

ken

corrections for b and c:
> > 
> > (b) Species are not killed off if their a=
verage fitness falls below a certain

at, if turned on, would kill off a species
> > if its maximum fitness has n=
ot improved in some number of generations.  That

ant species.

> > (c) "Stolen babies" is almost never used in any exper=
iment that I have seen

y an important mechanism.
> > However, it is a way to increase greediness. =
 As Daniel rightly infers, it
> > doesn't steal actual genetic code from on=
e species, but rather it steals the
> > *right* to reproduce from the worse=
 species and redistributes that right to
> > the better ones.  So sort of R=
obin Hood in reverse (steal from the poor to
> > help the rich).  
> > 
> >=
 In terms of "weighting the number of offspring produced towards the strong=
er
> > species," that is correct, but that is just a property of fitness sh=
aring,
> > which NEAT uses. 
> > 
> > In general, the most important select=
ion mechanism in NEAT is in fact fitness
> > sharing, which makes it diffic=
ult for good species to take over the entire
> > population because individ=
uals must share the fitness of their species.  So as
> > a species gets big=
ger, the fitness of everyone within it drops.  I would
> > consider fitness=
 sharing essential to NEAT's "identity."
> > 
> > However, all fitness shar=
ing does is adjust the fitnesses of everyone in the
> > population.  So aft=
er that, there is still a need to decide how many
> > offpspring individual=
s get.  It is at this point that versions of NEAT may
> > diverge and I do =
not have a strong opinion because I do not consider the
> > choice essentia=
l to NEAT's identity.
> > 
> > In my own implementations, first, offspring =
numbers are assigned on a
> > per-species basis (proportionally to *adjuste=
d* fitness after fitness sharing)
> > and then they are assigned within to =
species to individuals.  My version of
> > NEAT usually uses truncation sel=
ection within species.  So it just cuts out
> > the bottom n% of the specie=
s from being eligible to reproduce and the rest get
> > to reproduce.  (rtN=
EAT is different of course since it only produces one at a
> > time - it pr=
obabilistic).  The remaining individuals are selected as parents
> > random=
ly.
> > 
> > Perhaps most appealing for me about this approach is the idea =
that each
> > species can be treated as its own little mini-population in w=
hich whatever
> > selection scheme you choose is implemented.  I think it m=
akes conceptual sense
> > to think of a species as a population because *wi=
thin* a species one wants the
> > same kind of healthy phenomena to happen =
that one wants in a regular GA with a
> > full population.
> > 
> > Of cour=
se, you could alternatively choose roulette wheel selection within
> > spec=
ies (after adjusting fitness for fitness sharing) or something else.  That
=
> > choice is not that important, and I have tried a number of schemes and =
found
> > that, at least with NEAT, it makes limited difference which one i=
s chosen.
> > But the fitness sharing is still key.
> > 
> > So Jeff, there=
 is no simple to answer to "what kind of selection scheme does
> > NEAT use=
" because it is a multi-level scheme that first acts at the level of
> > sp=
eciation and then at the level of individuals within species.  So no one
> =
> blanket terms really covers the whole thing.  To distill it to a short ph=
rase,
> > perhaps we could say it uses "fitness sharing and any other schem=
e after
> > fitness-sharing."
